Science.definition: A testable explanation for an observation that can be supported or refuted through experimentation.
A factor in an experiment that can change or be controlled.
The group in an experiment that does not receive the independent variable and is used for comparison.
A community of living organisms interacting with each other and with their physical environment.
The process by which plants use light energy to convert carbon dioxide and water into glucose and oxygen.
The process in which cells break down glucose and oxygen to release energy, carbon dioxide, and water.
A type of cell division that results in two identical daughter cells.
The molecule that carries genetic information in living organisms.
The smallest unit of an element that retains the properties of that element.
Two or more atoms that are chemically bonded together.
The force of attraction between objects with mass.
An observation that describes qualities or characteristics without using numbers.
An observation that uses numbers or measurements to describe what is observed.
The process by which organisms maintain stable internal conditions despite external changes.
The factor that is purposely changed in an experiment to test its effect.
The factor that is measured in an experiment and changes in response to the independent variable.
A systematic process of asking questions, forming hypotheses, conducting experiments, and drawing conclusions.
The theory explaining the movement of Earth's lithospheric plates and the activity at their boundaries.
The preserved remains, impression, or trace of an organism from the past.
The movement of energy from one object or system to another.
The amount of matter in an object.
Mass per unit volume of a substance (D = M/V).
The amount of three-dimensional space an object occupies.
A pure substance consisting of one type of atom.
A substance formed by chemically combining two or more elements.
Physical blend of substances not chemically combined.
Process that forms new substances with different properties.
Change that affects form or appearance without creating a new substance.
Liquid changing to gas at the surface.
Gas changing to liquid.
Any form of water falling from clouds to Earth.
Green pigment in plants that captures light energy.
Organism that makes its own food (usually via photosynthesis).
Organism that eats other organisms for energy.
Organism that breaks down dead matter returning nutrients to soil.
Linear sequence of energy transfer between organisms.
Interconnected network of food chains in an ecosystem.
Variety of life in an ecosystem.
Trait that improves survival or reproduction.
Process where organisms with favorable traits reproduce more.
Change in species over generations.
Force opposing motion between touching surfaces.
Rate of change of velocity.
Speed in a given direction.
Resource naturally replenished on a human time scale.
Resource that forms slowly and cannot be quickly replaced.
Warming caused by gases trapping heat in atmosphere.
Long-term average weather conditions.
Day-to-day atmospheric conditions.
Diffusion of water through a selectively permeable membrane.
Movement of particles from high to low concentration.
Segment of DNA coding for a trait.
Trait expressed when at least one dominant allele is present.
Trait expressed only with two recessive alleles.
Group of similar organisms that can produce fertile offspring.
Environment where an organism lives.
Role an organism plays in its ecosystem.
Continuous movement of water through evaporation, condensation, precipitation.
Movement of carbon through atmosphere, organisms, soil, oceans.
A push or pull on an object.
SI unit of force.
Scale of acidity/basicity (0–14).
Substance with pH < 7 producing H+ ions.
Substance with pH > 7 producing OH- ions.
Reaction of acid and base forming water and a salt.
Heat transfer through direct contact.
Heat transfer by movement of fluids.
Energy transfer via electromagnetic waves.
Device (lever, pulley, etc.) that changes force or direction.

Math.definition: A whole number that can be positive, negative, or zero.
A number that represents a part of a whole or a part of a set.
A number that uses a decimal point to show a value smaller than one.
A ratio that compares a number to 100.
A comparison of two quantities by division.
An equation stating that two ratios are equivalent.
A mathematical statement that shows two expressions are equal.
A symbol, usually a letter, that represents an unknown value.
The number that is multiplied by a variable in an algebraic expression.
A mathematical phrase that can contain numbers, variables, and operations.
A mathematical statement that compares two expressions using greater than, less than, or equal to symbols.
A measure of the steepness of a line, found by the ratio of rise over run.
An equation in the form ax² + bx + c = 0, where a, b, and c are constants and a ≠ 0.
A function whose graph is a straight line.
A formula that relates the side lengths of a right triangle: a² + b² = c².
The average of a set of numbers, found by adding the numbers and dividing by how many there are.
The middle value in an ordered set of numbers.
The number that appears most often in a set of data.
The difference between the highest and lowest values in a data set.
The likelihood that an event will occur, expressed as a ratio, fraction, or percent.
A number that divides another number evenly.
The product of a number and any whole number.
A whole number greater than 1 that has exactly two factors: 1 and itself.
A whole number greater than 1 that has more than two factors.
The total distance around the outside of a shape.
The amount of surface covered by a shape.
The amount of space a three-dimensional object occupies.
The distance around a circle.
A small number written above and to the right of a base number that shows how many times the base is multiplied by itself.
The rules that tell you the correct sequence to evaluate a mathematical expression (PEMDAS).
Distance of a number from zero on the number line.
Multiplicative inverse of a number (a * 1/a = 1).
Rate with a denominator of one (e.g., miles per hour).
Linear equation form y = mx + b.
Linear equation form y - y1 = m(x - x1).
Linear equation form Ax + By = C.
Relation assigning exactly one output to each input.
Set of all input values for a function.
Set of all output values for a function.
Number not expressible as a fraction; non-repeating decimal.
Coordinates (x, y) locating a point.
Plane defined by perpendicular x and y axes.
Graph showing relationship between paired data.
Line best approximating a data set's trend.
Average distance of each data point from the mean.
Arrangement where order matters.
Selection where order does not matter.
Principal × Rate × Time.
Interest added to principal causing exponential growth.
Original amount invested or borrowed.
Current amount owed or saved.
Figures with equal angles and proportional sides.
Figures identical in size and shape.
Slide of a figure without rotation.
Turn of a figure around a point.
Flip of a figure across a line.
Resizing a figure proportionally from a center point.
Distance from circle center to edge.
Distance across circle through center (2r).
πr².
πr²h.
Triangle with one 90° angle.
Longest side of a right triangle.
Value which produces original when squared.
Number multiplied by itself three times.
Number which produces original when cubed.
Inequality containing a linear expression.
Two or more equations with shared variables.
Values satisfying all equations in a system.
Solve system by replacing a variable with an expression.
Solve system by combining equations to remove a variable.
Percent increase or decrease from original value.
Shape formed by combining simpler shapes.
Sequence with constant difference between consecutive terms.
Sequence with constant ratio between consecutive terms.
Probability based on trials or experiments.
Probability based on all possible outcomes.
Graph summarizing data using quartiles.
Difference between Q3 and Q1 (middle 50%).
Data point far from the rest of a set.

Reasoning Through Language Arts (RLA).definition: The central point or most important concept that an author wants the reader to understand.
Information that explains, proves, or enhances the main idea.
A conclusion reached by using evidence from the text and your own reasoning.
The author's attitude toward the subject or audience.
The underlying message or lesson the author wants to convey.
A sentence that states the main point or argument of an essay.
The sentence that expresses the main idea of a paragraph.
A word or phrase that connects ideas and helps writing flow smoothly.
Facts, examples, or details used to support a claim.
A statement or position that requires support.
An opposing viewpoint that challenges the writer's claim.
The specific group of readers or listeners a text is written for.
The reason why an author writes a text: to inform, persuade, entertain, or explain.
Words or expressions that go beyond literal meaning, such as metaphors and similes.
A comparison between two unlike things without using like or as.
A comparison between two unlike things using the words like or as.
The emotional or cultural meaning attached to a word.
The literal, dictionary definition of a word.
Hints within a sentence or paragraph that help the reader determine the meaning of an unfamiliar word.
Improving a draft by adding, removing, or rearranging ideas for clarity and effectiveness.
Correcting grammar, spelling, and punctuation errors in a draft.
Reviewing a final draft carefully to catch small errors before publishing.
Writing that aims to convince the reader to accept a viewpoint or take a specific action.
Writing that tells a story with characters, setting, and plot.
Nonfiction writing that provides facts about a topic.
The perspective from which a story is told.
A storytelling perspective in which the narrator is a character in the story and uses words like I and we.
A storytelling perspective where the narrator is outside the story and uses words like he, she, or they.
A text structure that presents events in the order they happened.
A text structure that explains why something happens and the result of it.
Repetition of initial consonant sounds in nearby words.
Giving human traits to non-human objects or ideas.
Deliberate exaggeration for emphasis.
Pair of contradictory words (e.g., jumbo shrimp).
Restate text in your own words while keeping meaning.
Condense main ideas without details.
Two or more sentences incorrectly joined.
Incomplete sentence missing subject or predicate.
Rule that subjects and verbs must match in number.
Word replacing a noun.
Noun a pronoun refers to.
Subject performs the action.
Subject receives the action.
Using same grammatical pattern for related ideas.
Group of words with a subject and verb.
Clause that can stand alone.
Clause that cannot stand alone.
Using different sentence patterns for effect.
Connector showing relationship (however, therefore).
Claim supported by evidence and reasoning.
Unfair preference toward one side.
Statement proven true.
Personal belief not provable.
Casual language for familiar audience.
Objective, professional language.
Reference giving credit to source.
Using others' words or ideas without credit.
Direct connection of evidence to claim.
Trustworthiness of a source.
Surrounding words or situation clarifying meaning.
Non-literal meaning expressed by figures of speech.
Exact dictionary meaning.
Conversation between characters.
Time and place of a story.
Sequence of events in a story.
Struggle between opposing forces.
Outcome of the conflict.
Hints of future events.
Scene showing past events.
Contrast between expectation and reality.
Use of symbols to represent ideas.
Descriptive language appealing to senses.
Act of influencing with reasoning or emotion.
Adjusting writing for intended readers.
Main claim of an essay.
Facts or details backing a claim.
Opposing point addressed in writing.
Improving ideas, organization, clarity.
Final check for small errors.
Reasoned conclusion from clues.

Social Studies.definition: A system of government in which citizens hold the power to make decisions through voting.
A form of government in which citizens elect representatives to make decisions on their behalf.
A written plan that outlines the structure, powers, and limits of a government.
A change or addition to a legal or governmental document, such as the U.S. Constitution.
A system of government in which power is divided between a national government and state governments.
The division of government responsibilities into distinct branches to prevent any one branch from becoming too powerful.
A system that allows each branch of government to limit the powers of the other branches.
The right to vote in political elections.
The rights of citizens to political and social freedom and equality.
The development of industries in a country or region on a wide scale.
The growth of cities and the movement of people from rural areas to urban centers.
The movement of people into a country from another country.
The spread of cultural beliefs and practices from one group to another.
The system by which goods and services are produced, distributed, and consumed.
A general increase in prices and a decrease in the purchasing value of money.
The total value of all goods and services produced in a country during a specific time period.
The relationship between the amount of a product available and the desire of buyers for it, which affects price.
An original document or firsthand account created at the time of an event.
A document or account that interprets or analyzes primary sources.
The 19th-century belief that the United States was destined to expand across the North American continent.
The period after the U.S. Civil War when southern states were reorganized and reintegrated into the Union.
A severe worldwide economic downturn that took place during the 1930s.
The period of political tension and military rivalry between the United States and the Soviet Union after World War II.
The first ten amendments to the U.S. Constitution that protect individual liberties.
The branch of government responsible for making laws.
The branch of government responsible for enforcing laws.
The branch of government responsible for interpreting laws and administering justice.
A form of government in which a single person, such as a king or queen, rules for life.
A tax imposed on imported goods.
A formal agreement between two or more countries.
Branch that makes laws.
Branch that enforces laws.
Branch that interprets laws.
Movement of African Americans to northern cities (1910–1970).
Programs addressing Great Depression under FDR.
Nonviolent refusal to obey unjust laws.
Movement to end slavery.
Formal approval of a document or amendment.
Biased information used to shape opinion.
Policy of avoiding foreign alliances.
Increasing interconnectedness of economies and cultures.
Spending exceeding revenue.
Revenue exceeding spending.
Plan for income and expenditures.
Government order restricting trade.
System of raising money for public needs.
Extended severe economic downturn.
Temporary economic decline.
Era of rapid industrial growth beginning in 18th century.
1863 order freeing slaves in Confederate states.
Granted citizenship and equal protection.
Prohibited denying vote based on race.
Granted women voting rights.
Process used to elect U.S. President.
Advisory heads of executive departments.
Highest U.S. court.
Court power to declare laws unconstitutional.
Fair treatment through justice system.
Freedom from oppressive control.
Equal rights and status.
Citizen responsibility to participate.
Inherent rights (life, liberty, property).
Government ruled by a small group.
Government under one absolute ruler.
System seeking complete control over life.
Removal of large areas of forest.
Separation of groups by race or other trait.
Annual plan of government revenues and spending.
Basic rights and freedoms for all people.
Formal pact between nations.
Tax on imported goods.
Belief U.S. should expand across continent.
Period of tension between U.S. and Soviet Union.
Severe worldwide downturn in 1930s.
Era of rebuilding after Civil War.
Entering a new country to live.
